meta_data.title: Deconstruction Story Series // John Redfearn Jr. and Deconstruction in Christian Music

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legge and Bren Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to Reconstructed Faith. This is Bren Starnes, your temporary host for today. I have a guest with me, John Redfern. Colson Lechner is on vacation with his wife, so we're excited for him to do that. Get a break. Away from their wonderful but small children. They've got a little tribe now with three of them running around. Very close together, so we're excited for them to get some rest hopefully. Then Chris is doing the opposite. He's taking a bunch of kids on a trip. He's taking a bunch of high schoolers to D.C. It is exactly the opposite. That's exactly what that is. That's so funny. I took some high schoolers to D.C. in college, and I just remember our leadership being like, okay, so it's up to you to get them on and off the subway and make sure they don't get lost. I was like, do you realize I'm 19? No. Things are different now, and everybody has to be reminded. I got this from Chris. They are an active participant in their own survival. Sometimes I want to say that to my children. I'm like, what? Guys! I cannot be... What is going on? I probably can't say that to Jack yet. He's only three months old. No, he's not an active participant in his own survival. Very passive. Trying to figure it out. Anyway, today I thought that I had a couple of things that I really want to pick John's brain about. Since Cole's is not here, we really can talk about anything we want. The only control he has is whether or not to pose. That's right. Suppose he's going to edit the fire out of this, make us say whatever he wants. Yeah. But today, I thought it would be interesting to talk about deconstruction in the realm of music and musicians. You can give some of your backstory if you want. You've been a musician for a long time. Yeah. I was really involved in the music ministries at church and was in band and school. I had to choose between band and choir, and I chose band because that's way cooler because I was a percussionist than being an choir nerd. I was a band geek. I was a percussionist, loved drumming and drumline and everything like that. It was just so cool. I was so enamored with it. And then when I was 15, I felt called to the ministry. So when I was 17, I think I learned how to play the guitar because it's really hard to lead from the drum set. But I was involved in a really traditional worship service at church. So when I was at church, I was in the orchestra. Okay. We didn't have guitars. We didn't have drums. We had a piano and a organ. And we had every once in a while we would have the orchestra play with us. So I got to play like the timpani and the suspended cymbal. I don't even know what one of those is. Oh, it's fine. But just which one do you not know? The timpani. Oh, that's the big kettle drums that you tune and then you play. Oh, yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Okay. Anyway, that was really fun. Anyway, but did all of that and then went to college to study music. Only lasted. I think I only lasted a semester in the middle of my college freshman year. We my father had he was pastoring at a church and there was there was a real big difference between him and the Deacon board and their vision for the church and their anyway, some of that got real ugly and he got accused of some things that he never did. And then there was basically a you know, the people were going to bring stuff up in front of the church that was going to split the church. Wasn't accurate, but it doesn't have to be. And so dad decided to step down and I was really hurt by that. And it all came to a head right when we were about to have some weird concert. I don't even remember what it was. And I was supposed to play in it, but like my family's falling apart, not falling apart, but my family is under attack. And so we had a guy that was going to fly me in. Oh, no, that came in later. So I was going to drive home and I was like, I'm sorry. I told the band director like or the band director, hey, I am really sorry, but like this is a really big deal that this is happening to my family. I feel like I need to be with them right now. My sisters are on their way, if not already there. And I need to be with my father and he and my advisor met with me and were like, listen, we know it's a big deal, but you're not going to feel that way forever. And we really need you to be here for this concert. Thanks. And so I kind of like. Grinned and buried it. It was like, OK, and so we did the concert and then the next day I got on a plane that somebody else paid for. So one of dad's friends paid for me to fly in and they went and got me and brought me to, you know, my family and. And at that point, I decided two things. I decided I was not going to be on staff at a church. And I also decided that. I wasn't going to be a music major at O.B.U. anymore. And so switch from music. Actually, if you if you stick in music major for your first year, you get you get a music minor because basically all of your you don't do any core classes as a freshman. Yeah, as a music major, you do all music. And so I had. Like 21 hours worth of credit in the first semester for that. All like everything, my first two semesters went towards my minor. And then I get a minor. So I have a music minor, but I have a Bible major because if I was going to study anything for the next three years. It should be the Bible. That was that was kind of a strange thing for me because it really did like I think it defined a lot of why. My deconstruction has gone differently than everybody else's. And I don't like I say that I think that. I think that everyone needs to deconstruct. We've talked about this totally. Everyone needs to to be able to ask hard questions. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

Like the only person made for glory was God.
Right.
And the only one made to be worshiped was God.
And anyone else can't stand under that pressure.
No. And maybe that's another part of it is that we were supposed to be mirrors of glasses
that are reflecting His glory.
If you start to think that you're the sun, that's a dangerous place for the moon to be.
Yeah.
And so, I mean, I don't know, like there's there's just I think there's.
Anytime I hear about these things happening, I am humbled because I know
that this is not done lightly.
Yeah, these people aren't whoever they are.
They're not they're not stupid.
Yeah, they're really smart.
They're not unfaithful.
Yeah.
Whatever word you want to kind of slap on somebody.
It's a really hard thing.
And I think that for me, this this has a lot to do with, again, I don't know if Chris has
talked about this on this podcast, but he's talked about it with me before that.
The only problem with midlife crisis.
Yes, I love that.
Is that they aren't happening often enough.
The only part I love this meaning.
Yes, it's very very true, but also makes a lot of sense.
The only problem with deconstruction is that it's happening not often enough.
Yeah.
And maybe at a breaking point before.
And that's the thing is if you if your Christianity
is if if your view of God, if your submission to God is this thing that every once in a while
is a brick in your house that that sometimes you know is is part of it's right next to your pride.
It's right next to your you know love of cars.
I mean, specific to myself here or your love of
you know, this thing or that thing or whatever.
If that's if that's the way that your view of your faith is, it's mixed in with your whatever.
It's like you're putting the foundation in the wrong place.
And the foundation needs to be the foundation.
Yeah, like Christ needs to be the foundation.
So check your foundation.
Walk around make sure that you're like not doing this wrong.
I'm not I'm not opposed to people asking hard questions about this faith.
Even if they're in a place of leadership.
Even if they're in a place of leadership, especially if they're in a place of
leadership, but they need to be asking those questions often.
Yeah.
And they need to remember that they were once convinced of something
in their mind, not because of their emotion.
Because of reason because of whatever and their emotion
gathered that and embraced it and you know rocket fueled it.
That's great.
But it is not driven by it.
And so there's I don't know,
like we're all going to we're all going to have Bonhoeffer says that the word of
God in the mouth of my brother is stronger than the word in my heart.
If you are being isolated, if you're feeling isolated either because you're
on top of the world and everybody else is beneath you or you're under,
you know, in the darkest pit and nobody else could understand what you're going through.
You have to be with brothers.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up.
Trust God.
Search for answers.
